elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Syntheses and structural characterization of four new cadmium(II)-)-hexamethylenetetramine (hmt) complexes with isomeric nitrobenzoates reveal that noncovalent interactions play a very important role in determining the final molecular structures of the self-assembled species.

</ce:simple-para><ce:para id="p0155" view="all">Self-assembled coordination complexes of Cd(II) with hmt.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0160" view="all">Very low angle between two hmt moieties in one compound.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0165" view="all">Noncovalent interactions lead to formation of polymers.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st110">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">Four new cadmium(II)-)–hexamethylenetetramine (hmt) complexes {[Cd(2-nbz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-hmt)(OH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>

</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Cd(3-nbz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(hmt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2(3-nbzH) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), [Cd(3-nbz)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-hmt)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and {[Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4-nbz)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-hmt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) with three isomeric nitrobenzoates, [2-nbz<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2-nitrobenzoate, 3-nbz<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3-nitrobenzoate and 4-nbz<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4-nitrobenzoate] have been synthesized and structurally characterized by X-ray crystallography. Their identities have also been established by elemental analyses and IR studies. Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a monomer. Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are 1D chains, with varied stereo arrangements. The presence of coordinating water and non-coordinating 3-nbzH molecules change the stereo arrangement of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> from that of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, which is devoid of both these types of molecules. In <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, two nitrogen atom of hmt coordinate to Cd(II) ion with N-–Cd-–N angle 114.4°. Various weak forces, i.e. π–π, CH–π and cation–π interactions play a key role in stabilizing the observed structures. This series of complexes demonstrates that although the nitro group does not coordinate to the metal center, its presence at the 2-, 3- or 4- position of the phenyl ring has a striking effect on the dimensionality as well as the structure of the resulted coordination polymers, probably due to the participation of the nitro group in cation⋯π and/or C-–H⋯π interactions.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ Self-assembled coordination complexes of Cd(II) with hmt.   ⋅ Very low angle between two hmt moieties in one compound.   ⋅ Noncovalent interactions lead to formation of polymers.   

Self-assembled coordination complexes of Cd(II) with hmt.

Very low angle between two hmt moieties in one compound.

Noncovalent interactions lead to formation of polymers.

Abstract

Four new cadmium(II)-)-hexamethylenetetramine (hmt) complexes {[Cd(2-nbz)2(μ2-hmt)(OH2)]⋅2H2O} n  (1), [Cd(3-nbz)2(hmt)2(OH2)2]⋅2(3-nbzH) (2), [Cd(3-nbz)4(μ2-hmt)] n  (3) and {[Cd2(4-nbz)4(μ2-hmt)2(OH2)2]⋅H2O} n  (4) with three isomeric nitrobenzoates, [2-nbz=2-nitrobenzoate, 3-nbz=3-nitrobenzoate and 4-nbz=4-nitrobenzoate] have been synthesized and structurally characterized by X-ray crystallography. Their identities have also been established by elemental analyses and IR studies. Complex 2 is a monomer. Complexes 1, 3 and 4 are 1D chains, with varied stereo arrangements. The presence of coordinating water and non-coordinating 3-nbzH molecules change the stereo arrangement of complex 2 from that of 3, which is devoid of both these types of molecules. In 3, two nitrogen atom of hmt coordinate to Cd(II) ion with N--Cd--N angle 114.4°. Various weak forces, i.e. π-π, CH-π and cation-π interactions play a key role in stabilizing the observed structures. This series of complexes demonstrates that although the nitro group does not coordinate to the metal center, its presence at the 2-, 3- or 4- position of the phenyl ring has a striking effect on the dimensionality as well as the structure of the resulted coordination polymers, probably due to the participation of the nitro group in cation⋯π and/or C--H⋯π interactions.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st005">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Metallo-supramolecular assemblies (both discrete and extended) have received a lot of attention recently as they often exhibit interesting molecular architectures and/or unusual properties . The supramolecular architecture is often constructed from small molecular and ion subunits by coordinate covalent bonds, hydrogen bonds, π-–π, C-–H/π and cation–π interactions . The mode of assembly of such extended supramolecular architectures can be tuned and predicted by careful selection of the chemical structure of organic ligands. In spite of the humongous increase in the construction of diverse architectures, the control of dimensionality is still a major challenge as the network topologies based on molecular building blocks are usually controlled and modified by the selection of the coordination geometry of the central metal atom, the structure of organic ligands, the nature of solvent used, and the ratio of metal salt to organic ligand. It is obvious that by judicious choice of central metal atom and organic spacer, it is possible to create complexes with interesting architecture . It has been observed that the polycyclic tertiary amine, hexamethylenetetramine (hmt), is a versatile ligand with the capability of adopting different coordination modes spanning from terminal monodentate to bridging bi-, tri- and tetradentate and the resulting coordination polymers exhibit enormous numbers of topologies including linear, zigzag, double, triple and quadruple one-dimensional chains as well as rectangular grids, flat and undulating two dimensional layers and cubic diamondoid complex three-dimensional networks . The metal ion Cd(II) is well suited for the construction of various coordination polymers, as its size and d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> electronic configuration permit a wide variety of coordination numbers and geometries specially with hmt .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metallo-supramolecular assemblies (both discrete and extended) have received a lot of attention recently as they often exhibit interesting molecular architectures and/or unusual properties . The supramolecular architecture is often constructed from small molecular and ion subunits by coordinate covalent bonds, hydrogen bonds, π--π, C--H/π and cation-π interactions . The mode of assembly of such extended supramolecular architectures can be tuned and predicted by careful selection of the chemical structure of organic ligands. In spite of the humongous increase in the construction of diverse architectures, the control of dimensionality is still a major challenge as the network topologies based on molecular building blocks are usually controlled and modified by the selection of the coordination geometry of the central metal atom, the structure of organic ligands, the nature of solvent used, and the ratio of metal salt to organic ligand. It is obvious that by judicious choice of central metal atom and organic spacer, it is possible to create complexes with interesting architecture . It has been observed that the polycyclic tertiary amine, hexamethylenetetramine (hmt), is a versatile ligand with the capability of adopting different coordination modes spanning from terminal monodentate to bridging bi-, tri- and tetradentate and the resulting coordination polymers exhibit enormous numbers of topologies including linear, zigzag, double, triple and quadruple one-dimensional chains as well as rectangular grids, flat and undulating two dimensional layers and cubic diamondoid complex three-dimensional networks . The metal ion Cd(II) is well suited for the construction of various coordination polymers, as its size and d10 electronic configuration permit a wide variety of coordination numbers and geometries specially with hmt .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">It has been observed in many systems that weak forces combine to play a decisive role in supramolecular architecture and hence are quite important in crystal engineering for the design of functional materials . Among the various weak forces, cation–π interactions involving metal cations, particularly alkali metal cations, have been investigated most thoroughly . There are some examples of studies of cation–π interactions involving organic cations . We would like to explore if an apparently innocent substitution in the phenyl ring of benzoate ion can bring about changes in the molecular architecture of their Cd(II) complexes with hexamethylenetetramine (hmt). Earlier we have investigated Cd(II)-)–benzoate system with hmt and found a wide variety of structures with <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>- and <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-bridging modes of hmt . Architectural changes viz. 1D chain to 3D polymer, are also observed for the analogous phenylacetate , with hmt in <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> bridging mode and maleate  terephthalate  and malonate , where the hmt is in <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> bridging mode.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It has been observed in many systems that weak forces combine to play a decisive role in supramolecular architecture and hence are quite important in crystal engineering for the design of functional materials . Among the various weak forces, cation-π interactions involving metal cations, particularly alkali metal cations, have been investigated most thoroughly . There are some examples of studies of cation-π interactions involving organic cations . We would like to explore if an apparently innocent substitution in the phenyl ring of benzoate ion can bring about changes in the molecular architecture of their Cd(II) complexes with hexamethylenetetramine (hmt). Earlier we have investigated Cd(II)-)-benzoate system with hmt and found a wide variety of structures with μ 2- and μ 3-bridging modes of hmt . Architectural changes viz. 1D chain to 3D polymer, are also observed for the analogous phenylacetate , with hmt in μ 2 bridging mode and maleate  terephthalate  and malonate , where the hmt is in μ 3 bridging mode.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Here we report the synthesis of four new cadmium complexes {[Cd(2-nbz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-hmt)(OH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Cd(3-nbz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(hmt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2(3-nbzH) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), [Cd(3-nbz)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-hmt)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and {[Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4-nbz)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-hmt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) with three isomeric nitrobenzoates, [2-nbz<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2-nitrobenzoate, 3-nbz<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3-nitrobenzoate and 4-nbz<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4-nitrobenzoate]. In both the complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> the ligand is 3-nbz. <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a monomeric compound but <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is polymeric in nature. The presence of coordinated water molecules along with the non-coordinated carboxylic acid, 3-nbzH in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> may be responsible for this special topology. Various weak forces such as C-–H/π, π-–π, cation-–π interactions, along with H-bonds play an important role in stabilizing the different topologies.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Here we report the synthesis of four new cadmium complexes {[Cd(2-nbz)2(μ2-hmt)(OH2)]⋅2H2O} n  (1), [Cd(3-nbz)2(hmt)2(OH2)2]⋅2(3-nbzH) (2), [Cd(3-nbz)4(μ2-hmt)] n  (3) and {[Cd2(4-nbz)4(μ2-hmt)2(OH2)2]⋅H2O} n  (4) with three isomeric nitrobenzoates, [2-nbz=2-nitrobenzoate, 3-nbz=3-nitrobenzoate and 4-nbz=4-nitrobenzoate]. In both the complexes 2 and 3 the ligand is 3-nbz. 2 is a monomeric compound but 3 is polymeric in nature. The presence of coordinated water molecules along with the non-coordinated carboxylic acid, 3-nbzH in 2 may be responsible for this special topology. Various weak forces such as C--H/π, π--π, cation--π interactions, along with H-bonds play an important role in stabilizing the different topologies.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st010">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The nitrobenzoic acids, hexamethylenetetramine (hmt) and cadmium carbonate were purchased from Lancaster and were of reagent grade. They were used as received without further purification. Cd(2-nbz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and Cd(3-nbz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O were prepared in our laboratory by reacting cadmium carbonate with 2-nitrobenzoic acid and 3-nitrobenzoic acid respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

The nitrobenzoic acids, hexamethylenetetramine (hmt) and cadmium carbonate were purchased from Lancaster and were of reagent grade. They were used as received without further purification. Cd(2-nbz)2⋅2H2O and Cd(3-nbz)2⋅2H2O were prepared in our laboratory by reacting cadmium carbonate with 2-nitrobenzoic acid and 3-nitrobenzoic acid respectively.

<ce:section-title id="st045">Crystallographic studies</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Independent reflection data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were collected with Mo Kα radiation at 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K using the Oxford Diffraction X-Calibur CCD System. The crystals were positioned at 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm from the CCD and 321 frames were measured with a counting time of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s. Data analyses were carried out with the CrysAlis program . Suitable single crystals of complexes <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were mounted on a Bruker-AXS SMART APEX II diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator and Mo Kα (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073 71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) radiation. The crystals were positioned at 60<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm from the CCD. Frames (3<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>6<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0) were measured with a counting time of 5 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s at room temperature. The structures were solved using direct methods with the <ce:small-caps>shelxs</ce:small-caps>97 program . The non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were included in geometric positions and given thermal parameters equivalent to 1.2 times those of the atom to which they were attached. Hydrogen atoms on oxygen atoms in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were located in difference Fourier maps and refined with distance constraints. Structures were refined on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> with the <ce:small-caps>shelx</ce:small-caps>l97 program . There is a significant residual electron density peak in compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. Of the highest residual electron density peaks, some are close to the metal atom, others were refined but gave enormous thermal parameters so were confirmed as false peaks. Absorption corrections for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were carried out using the <ce:small-caps>abspack</ce:small-caps> program . Absorption corrections for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were carried out using the <ce:small-caps>sadabs</ce:small-caps> program . All calculations were carried out using <ce:small-caps>shelxs</ce:small-caps> 97 , <ce:small-caps>shelxl</ce:small-caps> 97 , <ce:small-caps>platon</ce:small-caps> 99 , <ce:small-caps>ortep</ce:small-caps>-32  and <ce:small-caps>wingx</ce:small-caps> system Ver-1.64 . Significant crystallographic data are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>. Dimensions in the metal coordination spheres are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic studies

Independent reflection data for 1 and 2 were collected with Mo Kα radiation at 150K using the Oxford Diffraction X-Calibur CCD System. The crystals were positioned at 50mm from the CCD and 321 frames were measured with a counting time of 10s. Data analyses were carried out with the CrysAlis program . Suitable single crystals of complexes 3 and 4 were mounted on a Bruker-AXS SMART APEX II diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator and Mo Kα (λ =0.71073 71073Å) radiation. The crystals were positioned at 60mm from the CCD. Frames (360) were measured with a counting time of 5 5s at room temperature. The structures were solved using direct methods with the shelxs97 program . The non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were included in geometric positions and given thermal parameters equivalent to 1.2 times those of the atom to which they were attached. Hydrogen atoms on oxygen atoms in 1, 2 and 4 were located in difference Fourier maps and refined with distance constraints. Structures were refined on F 2 with the shelxl97 program . There is a significant residual electron density peak in compound 4. Of the highest residual electron density peaks, some are close to the metal atom, others were refined but gave enormous thermal parameters so were confirmed as false peaks. Absorption corrections for 1 and 2 were carried out using the abspack program . Absorption corrections for 3 and 4 were carried out using the sadabs program . All calculations were carried out using shelxs 97 , shelxl 97 , platon 99 , ortep-32  and wingx system Ver-1.64 . Significant crystallographic data are summarized in  . Dimensions in the metal coordination spheres are given in  .

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Description of structures of complexes 1, 2, 3 and 4 

{[Cd(2-nbz)2(μ2-hmt)(OH2)]⋅2H2O} n  (1)

The structure of 1, a zigzag polymer, is shown in   together with the atomic numbering scheme in the metal coordination sphere. The cadmium atom is seven-co-ordinate with a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal structure being bonded to two bidentate ligands and a water molecule in the equatorial plane together with two nitrogen atoms from hmt ligands in axial positions.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0125" view="all">It is worthwhile comparing the structures of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. In complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> the ligand is 2-nbz and it forms a zigzag polymer where each cadmium atom is seven-coordinate with distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. In both the complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> the anionic ligand is 3-nbz and the geometry around the Cd(II) atoms is octahedral. However, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a monomer whereas <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is a zigzag chain. The non-coordinated carboxylic acid, 3-nbzH which is present in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> forms hydrogen bonds with hmt and thus restricts the hmt from polydenticity. In <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> the ligand is 4-nbz and each cadmium atom is six-coordinate with octahedral geometry. The coordination spheres around Cd(II) centers in both complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are the same, but complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, which is devoid of any non-coordinated carboxylic acid, is a zigzag polymer. There is neither a significant nor periodic change in Cd–O bond lengths due to the nitro substitution. Considerable π-–π interactions are observed in all the complexes, C-–H/π interactions are observed in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. In case of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, the coordinated water molecules form strong donor H-bonds with the oxygen atom of the lattice water molecules as well as with the nitrogen atom of hmt (in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and oxygen atom of the coordinated 4-nitrobenzoate (in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>). Similarly, in complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the coordinated water molecule forms hydrogen bonds with the oxygen atom of the coordinated nitrobenzoate of the same unit and a nitrogen atom of the hmt of a neighboring unit which leads to a hydrogen bonded 1D polymeric structure. In complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> no such hydrogen bonding is possible as it is devoid of any coordinating water molecule. Cation-–π interactions are observed in complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. Therefore, it may be suggested that weak forces such as C-–H/π, π-–π, cation-–π interactions along with H-bonds play an important role in stabilizing the different topologies.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is worthwhile comparing the structures of compounds 1-4. In complex 1 the ligand is 2-nbz and it forms a zigzag polymer where each cadmium atom is seven-coordinate with distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. In both the complexes 2 and 3 the anionic ligand is 3-nbz and the geometry around the Cd(II) atoms is octahedral. However, 2 is a monomer whereas 3 is a zigzag chain. The non-coordinated carboxylic acid, 3-nbzH which is present in 2 forms hydrogen bonds with hmt and thus restricts the hmt from polydenticity. In 4 the ligand is 4-nbz and each cadmium atom is six-coordinate with octahedral geometry. The coordination spheres around Cd(II) centers in both complexes 2 and 4 are the same, but complex 4, which is devoid of any non-coordinated carboxylic acid, is a zigzag polymer. There is neither a significant nor periodic change in Cd-O bond lengths due to the nitro substitution. Considerable π--π interactions are observed in all the complexes, C--H/π interactions are observed in complex 1. In case of complexes 1 and 4, the coordinated water molecules form strong donor H-bonds with the oxygen atom of the lattice water molecules as well as with the nitrogen atom of hmt (in 1) and oxygen atom of the coordinated 4-nitrobenzoate (in 4). Similarly, in complex 2, the coordinated water molecule forms hydrogen bonds with the oxygen atom of the coordinated nitrobenzoate of the same unit and a nitrogen atom of the hmt of a neighboring unit which leads to a hydrogen bonded 1D polymeric structure. In complex 3 no such hydrogen bonding is possible as it is devoid of any coordinating water molecule. Cation--π interactions are observed in complex 4. Therefore, it may be suggested that weak forces such as C--H/π, π--π, cation--π interactions along with H-bonds play an important role in stabilizing the different topologies.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0130" view="all">There are a few complexes of hmt and Cd(II) together with carboxylate ligands . Interestingly, in most of them, carboxylate groups act as bidentate chelating ligand and the hmt acts as an additional bridge between Cd(II) centers. In all the cases hmt has been found to be coordinated to cadmium ion in transoid fashion probably due to steric reason and consequently the N-–Cd-–N bond angle is around 180°. But in complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, two hmts are in cisoid fashion with bond angle 114.4(4)° which is unprecedented. Comparing the structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, with the structurally characterized complexes of hmt and Cd(II) together with carboxylate ligand  show that a slight variation in the carboxylate ligands can bring about a subtle change in the geometry around the metal centre, from hexa-coordinated, octahedral  to hepta-coordinated, pentagonal bipyramidal . The reason of this structural variation is still unknown. In these complexes the coordination mode of the hmt is -<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
 or -<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: There are a few complexes of hmt and Cd(II) together with carboxylate ligands . Interestingly, in most of them, carboxylate groups act as bidentate chelating ligand and the hmt acts as an additional bridge between Cd(II) centers. In all the cases hmt has been found to be coordinated to cadmium ion in transoid fashion probably due to steric reason and consequently the N--Cd--N bond angle is around 180°. But in complex 3, two hmts are in cisoid fashion with bond angle 114.4(4)° which is unprecedented. Comparing the structures of 1-4, with the structurally characterized complexes of hmt and Cd(II) together with carboxylate ligand  show that a slight variation in the carboxylate ligands can bring about a subtle change in the geometry around the metal centre, from hexa-coordinated, octahedral  to hepta-coordinated, pentagonal bipyramidal . The reason of this structural variation is still unknown. In these complexes the coordination mode of the hmt is -μ 2  or -μ 3 .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st080">I.R. spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0135" view="all">All four complexes show bands at ∼990–1007<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and 1225 –1238<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> due to CN stretching of hmt moiety. The strong bands at 1579–1600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for all complexes are due to the antisymmetric stretching mode of the carboxylate group. The prominent bands at ∼1405<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for all the complexes may be attributed to the symmetric stretching mode of the carboxylate group. The symmetric and antisymmetric stretching modes of the nitro group for all the complexes are observed at ∼1345<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and ∼1530<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> respectively. <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are observed at ∼830<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) for complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is at observed ∼805<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The broadband in the region of ∼3400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> could be assigned to the stretching vibration of the water molecules involved in hydrogen bonding.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
I.R. spectra

All four complexes show bands at ~990-1007cm-1 and 1225 -1238cm-1 due to CN stretching of hmt moiety. The strong bands at 1579-1600cm-1 for all complexes are due to the antisymmetric stretching mode of the carboxylate group. The prominent bands at ~1405cm-1 for all the complexes may be attributed to the symmetric stretching mode of the carboxylate group. The symmetric and antisymmetric stretching modes of the nitro group for all the complexes are observed at ~1345cm-1 and ~1530cm-1 respectively. δ(NO2) for complexes 1, 2 and 3 are observed at ~830cm-1. δ(NO2) for complex 4 is at observed ~805cm-1. The broadband in the region of ~3400cm-1 for complexes 1 and 4 could be assigned to the stretching vibration of the water molecules involved in hydrogen bonding.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st085">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0140" view="all">Four complexes are synthesized by using Cd(II), hmt and <ce:italic>o-,m-</ce:italic> or <ce:italic>p</ce:italic>-nitrobenzoate in water and characterized structurally. For all three isomeric nitrobenzoates (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), zigzag 1D coordination polymers are formed whereas compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a monomer. The presence of a non-coordinated 3-nbzH which forms hydrogen bonds with hmt restricts the hmt from bridging the metal ions in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. In <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, two nitrogen atom of hmt coordinate with Cd(II) ion with very low N-–Cd-–N bond angle which is unique. The coordination geometry around Cd(II) is pentagonal bipyramidal in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> but distorted octahedral in the other three. The H-bonding networks in the compounds vary significantly as different numbers of coordinated and lattice water molecules are present. The supramolecular C-–H/π, and π-–π interactions are also very different. Thus variations in the position of nitro group in the phenyl ring of nitrobenzoates bring about significant structural changes in the complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Four complexes are synthesized by using Cd(II), hmt and o-,m- or p-nitrobenzoate in water and characterized structurally. For all three isomeric nitrobenzoates (1, 3 and 4), zigzag 1D coordination polymers are formed whereas compound 2 is a monomer. The presence of a non-coordinated 3-nbzH which forms hydrogen bonds with hmt restricts the hmt from bridging the metal ions in 2. In 3, two nitrogen atom of hmt coordinate with Cd(II) ion with very low N--Cd--N bond angle which is unique. The coordination geometry around Cd(II) is pentagonal bipyramidal in 1 but distorted octahedral in the other three. The H-bonding networks in the compounds vary significantly as different numbers of coordinated and lattice water molecules are present. The supramolecular C--H/π, and π--π interactions are also very different. Thus variations in the position of nitro group in the phenyl ring of nitrobenzoates bring about significant structural changes in the complexes.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the complexes

{[Cd(2-nbz)2(μ2-hmt)(OH2)]⋅2H2O} n  (1)

To the synthesized Cd(2-nbz)2⋅2H2O (0.651g,1.35mmol) dissolved in 40ml hot water, hmt (0.189g, 1.35mmol) dissolved in 10ml water was added with constant stirring. The solution was then filtered and left at room temperature and after a few days colorless crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray determination was collected from the solution.

[Cd(3-nbz)2(hmt)2(OH2)2]⋅2(3-nbzH) (2)

To 3-nitrobenzoic acid (0.836g, 5mmol) dissolved in 50ml hot water, cadmium carbonate (0.517g, 3mmol) was added pinch by pinch. The mixture was stirred till effervescence ceased. The solution was then filtered, the volume of filtrate was reduced to ca.25ml by warming in a water bath and then hmt (0.560g, 4mmol) dissolved in 10ml water was added with constant stirring. The solution was left at room temperature and after a few days colorless crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray determination were collected from the solution.

[Cd(3-nbz)4(μ2-hmt)] n  (3)

Complex 3 was synthesized following the same procedure as that of complex 1 except that synthesized Cd(3-nbz)22H2O was used instead of Cd(2-nbz)22H2O.

Yield: 0.540g (47%). Anal. Calc. for C20H20CdN6O8 (584.82): C, 41.07; H, 3.45; N, 14.37; . Found: C, 41.11; H, 3.51; N, 14.30%. Selected IR peaks (cm-1): 1600, 1549, 1530, 1399, 1346, 992 and 833.

{[Cd2(4-nbz)4(μ2-hmt)2(OH2)2]⋅H2O} n  (4)

To 4-nitrobenzoic acid (0.836g, 5mmol) dissolved in 70ml hot water, cadmium carbonate (1.724g, 10mmol) was added pinch by pinch. The mixture was stirred till effervescence ceased. The solution was then filtered, the volume of filtrate was reduced to ca. 20ml by warming in a water bath and then hmt (0.560g, 4mmol) dissolved in 10ml water was added with constant stirring. The solution was left at room temperature and after a few days colorless crystals of 4 suitable for X-ray determination were collected from the solution. Yield: 0.325g (47%). Anal. Calc. for C20H25CdN6O10.5 (629.86): C, 38.14; H, 4.00; N, 13.34; . Found: C, 38.21; H, 4.03; N, 13.42%. Selected IR peaks (cm-1): 3396, 3058, 1587, 1535, 1391, 1343, 999 and 806.

Found: C, 37.34; H, 4.08; N, 13.20%. Selected IR peaks (cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3397, 1579, 1528, 1390, 1345, 1238, 1007 and 836.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Yield: 0.675<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (59%). <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">46</ce:inf>CdN<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf> (1095.29): C, 43.86; H, 3.23; N, 15.35; .
